questions.question: We …………………………… to Greece next summer.
questions.description: We use the present continuous tense to talk about pre-planned future events.

questions.question: I knew she ………………………….. before long.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: The Prime Minister ……………………………. London in December.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about plans and schedules.

questions.question: Phone me when you ………………………….
questions.description: In the subordinate clause we often use a present tense to refer to future.

questions.question: ‘I’m hungry.’ ‘I …………………………….. you something to eat.’
questions.description: We use the simple future to tell people about a decision as we make it.

questions.question: …………………………… I open the window?
questions.description: Shall I is often used to ask for instructions.

questions.question: I …………………………… you tonight.
questions.description: We use the simple future to announce our decisions.

questions.question: I will pay you back when I …………………………….. a job.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the future tense, we use a present tense in the subordinate clause to refer to future.

questions.question: By next year, we …………………………………. here for twenty-five years.
questions.description: We use the future perfect to say that something will have been achieved by a certain time in the future.

questions.question: I ………………………….. break his neck.
questions.description: With the first person pronouns we use will in threats.

questions.question: I promise I ………………………………. do that again.
It is no use phoning them now – they ………………………………….. by now.
questions.description: The future perfect can also be used to predict the present.
